I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation to support a major 
change in scope of the Supply Chain Finance Program (SCFP). This entails: 
(i)  the incorporation on a permanent basis of the following changes to the program, 
originally approved on a temporary basis as part of the Asian Development Bank’s  
(ADBs) Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic:1 
(a)  approval to enter into equitable assignments of trade receivables, trade 
credits, and trade-related loans;  
(b)  waiver  of  the  requirement  for  the  Investment  Committee  to  approve 
partner financial institutions (PFIs) to work with the SCFP where such PFIs 
have previously been approved by the Investment Committee to work with 
the Trade Finance Program (TFP); and  
(ii)  the ability to undertake unfunded risk participations in working capital loans and 
guarantees each with a maximum tenor of 12 months.  
 
2.  The proposed mainstreaming of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) specific scope 
changes will reduce small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) financing gaps and support their 
growth in developing member countries (DMCs) by: (i) broadening private sector support for 
supply chain finance and working capital facilities, (ii) improving cash flows to DMC companies to 
enable growth and job creation, and (iii) producing a demonstration effect that will encourage 
financial institutions to undertake more supply chain financing.  
 
3.  This report and recommendation also fulfils the reporting requirement to the Board on the 
program’s performance at intervals of no more than 3 years.  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.    Background 
4.  Substantial gaps exist in financing global trade. Closing those gaps will lead to growth for 
developing economies, more jobs for those who need them, and fewer people living in poverty. 
An International Finance Corporation study found that 40% of SMEs in developing economies 
have unmet financing needs.2 A trade finance gap survey carried out by the ADB confirmed a 
global trade finance gap of $1.5 trillion in 2019 and determined that 40% of this gap was in Asia 
and the Pacific, with 74% of rejected trade finance transactions coming from SMEs.3 Women-
owned firms find it even more difficult to access finance; the survey found that among women-
owned firms, the average rejection rate of their proposals was 44%, compared with 38% for male-
owned firms. Prior to the COVID-19 crisis, the World Economic Forum estimated that the global 
trade finance gap would rise to $2.5 trillion by 2025. However, with the adverse impact of the 
pandemic, the gap is already much larger. The International Chamber of Commerce anticipates 
that an additional $1.9 trillion−$5.0 trillion is needed to support a rapid global recovery.4  
 
 
1 ADB. 2020. ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic. Manila. 
2 International Finance Corporation. 2017. MSME Finance Gap. Washington, DC. 
3 ADB. 2019. Trade Finance Gaps, Growth, and Jobs Survey. ADB Briefs No. 113. September. Manila. 
4 International Chamber of Commerce. 2020. Trade Financing and COVID-19. Paris.

2 
 
5.  To reduce financing gaps, the ADB Board of Directors approved the launch of the SCFP 
in November 2012 with a limit of up to $200 million.5 The program was renewed in March 2018 
with an increased limit of $300 million and a change in scope.6  
 
6.  Supply chain finance is the provision of finance at various stages of the supply chain. This 
allows smaller entities such as DMC suppliers and distributors to receive finance to maintain or 
even increase their production and/or sales without being constrained by having to wait for receipt 
of payments from large buyers or pay in advance for purchase of goods from large sellers. 
Depending on the stage at which such finance is provided, there are different supply chain finance 
products, namely pre-shipment finance, post-shipment finance, and distributor finance.  
 
7.  ADB provides supply chain finance to suppliers, distributors, buyers, or sellers through 
PFIs only, by allowing the PFI to transfer a part of the default risk of corporates (usually 50%) to 
ADB and in some cases by funding the PFI for supply chain finance loans extended by the PFI to 
its customers. This permits PFIs to reduce their capital requirements and, in certain cases, to 
remove ADB’s share in the loans from their balance sheet, bringing further efficiency into capital 
allocation. The result is that PFIs have more capital resources to support SMEs in DMCs, which 
contributes to closing market gaps, boosting economic growth, and creating jobs. The SCFP 
complements the TFP. A key difference, however, is that while the SCFP assumes the default 
risk of corporates in the supply chain, the TFP assumes the risk of banks defaulting on trade 
finance instruments. 
 
8.  Unlike the TFP (approved in 2003), the SCFP had a difficult start because ADB lacked 
experience, risk models, risk acceptance criteria, operational procedures, and documentation to 
support supply chain finance. In addition to adding staff for the program, the special policy 
variations approved under the Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic (footnote 
1) have enabled the program to be better aligned with the market, resulting in heightened market 
interest and a broader pipeline of deals. ADB now has sufficient internal infrastructure and a 
strong growth strategy to underpin a successful supply chain finance business and to enhance its 
development impact. 
 
9.  To  scale  up  the  SCFP,  leveraging  the  TFP’s  trade  finance  operations  and  strong 
relationships with DMC banks built up through the TFP, joint efforts of the two programs were 
rebranded in 2020 as the Trade and Supply Chain Finance Program (TSCFP). The TSCFP 
reduces financing gaps by fostering closer engagement of the two programs and leveraging 
common internal resources. Notwithstanding this, the TFP and SCFP are referred to as separate 
programs in this document. 
 
B.    Program Performance  
10.  Utilization. Supply chain finance transactions are short-term, with an average tenor of 2 
or 3 months, which means each dollar of the $300 million limit can be used up to four times in a 
year. This is an efficient use of ADB’s capital resources. During the reporting period (2018–2020), 
the program supported 2,554 transactions (an increase of 301% over the previous 3-year period) 
valued at $582 million (an increase of 9% over the previous 3-year period). In 2020, the program 
supported 1,447 transactions (an increase of 151% over 2019) valued at $246 million (an increase 
of 108% over 2019); $162 million of that was cofinanced by PFIs. The program maintained this

Program. Manila. 
6 ADB. 2018. Regional: Proposed Loans, Guarantees, and Risk Participation Products – Major Change in Scope.

growth rate during the first quarter (Q) of 2021, when the program supported 517 transactions (an 
increase of 259% over Q1 2020) valued at $65 million (an increase of 110% over Q1 2020). The 
program anticipates that the current program limit will be sufficient to accommodate growth until 
the first half of 2023. 
 
11.  Strategy. The program’s strategy is based on the following: (i) scale the SCFP by building 
a strong PFI network with global and regional banks; (ii) diversify the SCFP geographically by 
building the capacity of the TFP’s DMC banks to develop their supply chain finance businesses 
and by increasing sectoral coverage; (iii) grow new supply chain finance markets by addressing 
regulatory  impediments  through  One  ADB  and  industry  partnerships;  (iv)  explore  new 
opportunities and collaborations with industry organizations; and (v) mobilize additional funding 
resources through risk distribution and cofinancing opportunities. 
 
12.  Sector composition, geographic composition, and support for small and medium-
sized  enterprises.  The  program  continues  to  increase  its  sectoral  reach  to  support  the 
pharmaceutical industry, medical distribution, food production, technology manufacturing and 
distribution, and garment retail distribution. Since its inception, the program has supported supply 
chains across 10 DMCs including Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Pakistan, the People’s 
Republic of China, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and Viet Nam. During the 3-year reporting 
period, the program supported 1,519 SME transactions. 
 
13.  Design and monitoring framework results. The program mostly exceeded the metrics 
set out in the design and monitoring framework appended to the program’s 2018 report and 
recommendation of the President (footnote 6).

14.  Pandemic response. The COVID-19 pandemic has strained supply chains throughout 
Asia, including for companies that manufacture and distribute food products, medical products, 
and  equipment. ADB’s  Comprehensive  Response to  the  COVID-19  Pandemic  (footnote  1) 
recognized the need to help DMCs deal with the crisis, to offset both the direct effects of the virus 
and  its  economic  repercussions.  The introduction  of  policy variations  under  the  COVID-19 
Response and changes in implementation arrangements for the program provided it with an 
enabling framework to support strained supply chains and respond to, or indirectly address, the 
economic impacts  of the  COVID-19  pandemic.  In the first  12 months after the  COVID-19

4 
 
Response changes were introduced (April 2020–April 2021), the program experienced a 183% 
increase in the number of transactions supported compared with the previous 12-month period.  
 
15.  Supply chain maps for pandemic-fighting products. The TSCFP, in partnership with 
other  ADB  departments,  developed  supply  chain  maps  for  pandemic-fighting  products,  an 
interactive tool to undertake end-to-end mapping of supply chains for critical pandemic-fighting 
goods such as ventilators, N95 masks, and other key products.7 The tool was updated in March 
2021 to include vaccine supply chains. This initiative enables users to identify companies involved 
in each component of the supply chain, to address any bottlenecks in liquidity, and identify support 
required by companies in these supply chains. 
 
C.    Knowledge Products and Capacity Building for Market Development  
16.  Although partnerships with global and regional banks under the program are producing 
positive development impacts, such PFIs tend to target more developed DMCs. To achieve 
greater geographic diversification, the program must attract more DMC banks as PFIs in addition 
to global and regional banks. However, supply chain finance is not sufficiently understood or 
developed in most DMCs to attract these DMC banks. To develop DMC banks’ capacity to offer 
supply chain finance to SMEs, capacity building and knowledge products are critical. The program 
addresses this in the following ways:  
(i)  Supply chain finance capacity development technical assistance. Targeted 
technical support is being delivered to a set of TFP DMC banks that have been 
assessed  for  their capacity  and commitment  to  build  a  supply chain  finance 
business. The SCFP aims to work with about 10 DMC banks from 2021 to end of 
2023  to  develop  supply  chain  finance  business  models,  with  a  view  to 
subsequently signing risk-sharing agreements with these banks to include them as 
PFIs.  Target markets  include  Bangladesh,  Indonesia,  Mongolia, Pakistan, Sri 
Lanka, Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam. The program anticipates that seven of these 
DMC banks will be onboarded as PFIs.  
(ii)  Seminars,  webinars,  or  industry  events.  The  program  deploys  significant 
resources to deepen knowledge of supply chain finance and promote market 
awareness of how this product has the potential to reduce financing gaps. Since 
2016, the program has provided seven seminars to more than 360 bankers from 
Fiji,  Kazakhstan,  Mongolia,  Thailand,  and  Uzbekistan,  and  e-training  for  380 
bankers across 23 DMCs. In 2020, the program stepped up the pace of this 
initiative to provide tailor-made webinars to selected TFP partner banks in DMCs 
targeted by the program to introduce supply chain finance. As of December 2020, 
more than 55 representatives from banks in Mongolia, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, and 
Uzbekistan have attended these webinars. In 2021, this initiative is being rolled out 
to Cambodia, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. More DMCs will be considered and included 
under this initiative in the next 3 years. 
 
D.    Lessons Learned 
17.  Initial product range was not aligned with shifting market practices. The temporary 
changes in scope under ADB’s Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic (footnote 
1) better aligned the program to the market and bolstered the program’s capacity to address 
financing gaps. Following approval of these scope changes, the program experienced strong 
growth in demand, resulting in a 108% increase in the total value of transactions supported in 
 
7   ADB. 2020. Supply Chain Maps for Pandemic-Fighting Products. Manila.

5 
 
2020 compared with 2019. Continuation of some of these scope changes (listed in paras. 17 [i], 
[ii],  and  [iii])  on  a  permanent  basis  would  continue  to  fuel  program  growth  and  maximize 
development impact.     
(i)  Equitable assignment. In 2018, the Bankers Association for Finance and Trade8 
reissued its industry standard documentation to use equitable assignments for 
participation in trade and supply chain finance assets, and banks have accordingly 
updated their systems to transfer risk on an equitable assignment basis. Under 
common accounting standards, an equitable assignment provides a more efficient 
mechanism  to  remove  assets  from  balance  sheets,  leading  to  lower  capital 
requirements  for  banks  and  balance sheet  efficiencies.  These  balance sheet 
efficiencies leave more capital resources for banks to support supply chain finance 
and SMEs in the value chain. As local banks look to establish supply chain finance 
programs in DMCs, they increasingly want to adopt this approach for efficient 
accounting treatment. 
(ii)  Risk participation in working capital loans. ADB’s ability to risk-participate with 
PFIs on an unfunded basis, in working capital loans and guarantees with tenors 
up to 6 months, is essential to enhancing support for transactions such as pre-
shipment  and  export  loans.  In  many  DMCs,  supply  chain  finance  is 
underdeveloped and is limited to banks offering simpler products such as loans 
and guarantees. For example, supplier finance is provided in the form of loans to 
buyers,  the  disbursement  of  which  is  only  permitted  for  supplier  payments. 
Furthermore,  distributor finance is  provided  in  the form  of  portfolio loans for 
working capital to a seller. Neither of these product variants, which can help PFIs 
roll out financing for SME suppliers and distributors at pace, could in the past be 
supported  by  the  program.  This  ability  has been invaluable  for the  SCFP  in 
addressing working capital requirements in supply chains. It broadens the universe 
of DMC suppliers and distributors that can be supported, subject to prevailing 
regulatory environment. The program has received strong market feedback to 
consider  increasing  the  tenor  of  the  supported  working  capital  loans  and 
guarantees to 12 months.  
(iii)  Simplified  approval  process.  Under  the standard SCFP, ADB’s  Investment 
Committee must approve PFIs before they can work under the program. However, 
most global and regional PFIs have already been approved under the TFP. ADB 
gains efficiencies internally and speeds up response times for clients by waiving 
the approval process for PFIs already approved under the TFP. This waiver 
enables the program to quickly onboard qualified new banks, channel immediate 
support, and mobilize cofinancing with global banks and eligible counterparties. 
 
18.  There is  an opportunity  to mobilize more  cofinancing, leverage  ADB’s  capital 
resources, and drive more development impact by distributing risk. Growth of the program 
in the coming years will reduce headroom under the current $300 million program limit. The 
program will manage the growing demand through a combination of effective limit management 
and  by  establishing  arrangements  to  distribute  risk  to  other  entities.  Cofinancing  through 
distribution will leverage ADB’s resources and help close market gaps for SMEs by crowding more 
private sector participation into supply chain finance, which will also result in more efficient use of 
ADB’s resources. The SCFP team is in discussions with insurance firms to pilot risk distribution 
starting  from  Q3  2021.  Opportunities  to  collaborate  and  share  risk  with  other  multilateral 
development banks and development finance institutions are also being explored. 
 
8  The Bankers Association for Finance and Trade is the leading industry body for organizations engaged in 
international transaction banking, including trade and supply chain finance.

6 
 
 
19.  The program can have deeper impact through geographic diversification, with a 
shift away from larger markets where global banks focus. This objective can be accomplished 
by expanding the program to include DMC banks as PFIs. However, supply chain finance either 
does not exist or is not well developed in most DMCs. There are two primary impediments to 
expanding supply chain finance in DMCs: (i) legislative gaps; and (ii) understanding of supply 
chain finance among banks and companies, including SMEs. On the regulatory side, the program 
team works with ADB resident missions and regional departments as well as with other industry 
bodies to advocate for policy reforms to establish a fit-for-purpose regulatory environment for 
supply  chain  finance.  On  the  knowledge  and  capacity  building  side,  in  markets  such  as 
Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Viet Nam where supply chain finance products are nascent and 
global PFIs do not have a large footprint, the program leverages strong TFP relationships and 
provides support to build the capacity of selected DMC banks in supply chain finance through TA 
(para. 16 [i]). It is expected that this TA will result in additional DMC banks being included in the 
program to share risk with ADB in supply chain finance transactions.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE  
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
20.  The program has achieved the objectives set out in the 2018 report and recommendation 
of the President (footnote 6). Except as set out in para. 21 below, it is proposed that the program, 
as previously approved, remain unchanged. 
 
21.  Continuation and expansion of scope changes. Based on the positive market response 
to  the  changes  in  scope  under  ADB’s  COVID-19  response,  which  enable  more  broad 
achievement of the program’s design and monitoring framework outcomes, it is proposed to make 
permanent  certain  of  those  changes  and  to  further  enhance  the  program’s  product  range 
as follows: 
 
(i)  Incorporation on a permanent basis of the following changes to the  program 
originally approved on a temporary basis under ADB’s Comprehensive Response 
to the COVID-19 Pandemic: 
(a)  approval  to  enter  into  risk  participation  through  equitable 
assignments of trade receivables, trade credits, and trade-related 
loans. This will enable the program to remain relevant and retain its ability 
to engage with banks, which are moving their business models to the 
equitable  assignment  methodology.  This  will  provide  a  more  efficient 
process to use ADB support and resources for incentivizing PFIs and their 
provision of supply chain finance in DMCs to support SMEs; and 
(b)  waiver  of  the  requirement  for  Investment  Committee  to  approve 
partner financial institutions to work with the program, where such 
institutions  have  previously  been  approved  by  the  Investment 
Committee to work with the Trade Finance Program. This will enable 
the program to maintain its agile response and allow faster mobilization of 
support.  
(ii)  Expansion of the program to support unfunded risk participation in working 
capital loans and guarantees, each with a maximum tenor of up to 12 months.  
This will enable the SCFP to engage with an increasing number of global and DMC 
banks to channel financing across more targeted stages of the supply chain 
relevant to companies in DMCs.

7 
 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  No changes are proposed to existing implementation arrangements.  
 
23.  Reporting  and  monitoring  arrangements.  The  terms  of  the  risk  participation  or 
guarantees with a PFI or loan agreements with obligors require that audited financial statements 
and strategy updates be provided at regular intervals or as requested. ADB will conduct an annual 
review of PFIs and obligors under the program in accordance with the Staff Instructions.9 In 
accordance with the 2018 report and recommendation of the President, ADB reports on the 
program to the Board at intervals of no more than 3 years (footnote 6). Accordingly, the next report 
on the program will be due in 2024.10 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
24.  Address finance gaps in supply chains. Supply chain finance is a unique product that 
can help address the trade finance gap in Asia and the Pacific, providing more timely access to 
working capital for SMEs. The $2 trillion in financeable payables globally identified by McKinsey 
& Company illustrates the untapped potential for supply chain finance.11 With the expanded scope 
of the program, ADB support will have a greater impact and will be more market-relevant. Support 
for SMEs under the program will help underpin economic growth and job creation in ADB DMCs. 
 
25.  Gender equality. The program aims to play a stronger role in addressing gender equality 
constraints in supply chains, recognizing that the women’s market is poorly understood and that 
limited data exists on corporate procurement and women-owned businesses. The revised design 
and monitoring framework of the program has incorporated additional gender features that will 
contribute to addressing these gaps, enabling an upgrade of gender categorization to effective 
gender mainstreaming.12 
 
D.  Risks 
 
26.  The 2018 report and recommendation of the President and the associated Program Risks 
addressed key risks and mitigation measures in implementing supply chain finance with a PFI.13 
These included differing levels of risk exposure at various stages in the supply chain, supplier 
performance,  obligor  credit  risk, nonperformance  of the PFI,  legal  and  documentation  risk, 
regulatory risk, operational risk, country risk, geographic and sectoral concentration risk, and 
currency risk.14 Given the addition of products like working capital loans, distributor finance, and 
pre-shipment finance, the Program has agreed with ADB‘s Office of Risk Management on product 
concentration limits to cap exposure to higher risk products. ADB‘s Office of Risk Management 
must approve all obligors under the program.

27.  Audit. ADB’s Office of the Auditor General (OAG) audited the program in 2020. OAG 
acknowledged that the program has adequate manual controls and well-established procedures. 
Automation through deployment of fit-for-purpose technology is a key actionable for the SCFP, 
which will be accomplished by 2024 for both TFP and SCFP transactions.  
 
IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Output 
 
28.  Impact.  The  program’s  revised  impact  is  capacity  of  domestic  financial  institutions 
strengthened to encourage and expand access to banking and financial services for all.15 This will 
be achieved by increasing access of DMC corporates to finance through supply chain finance. 
  
29.  Outcome. The revised program outcome is uptake of supply chain finance expanded in 
DMCs. Through a combination of knowledge products, loans, guarantees, and funded and 
unfunded risk participation, DMC SMEs and corporates will receive more financing and PFIs can 
leverage  ADB’s  participation  to  broaden  their  supply  chain  finance  portfolios.  Success  in 
achieving the outcome will be measured in terms of an increase in the number and value of supply 
chain transactions supported. 
 
30.  Outputs. The program’s outputs extend the capacity to provide supply chain finance, 
support its gender inclusivity, expand the banks’ training in supply chain financing and gender 
balance. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
31.  Consistency with ADB strategy. The program is consistent with Strategy 2030 and the 
overarching objective of achieving an Asia and Pacific region that is  prosperous, inclusive, 
resilient, and sustainable, and contributes to ADB´s Operational Priorities (OPs).16 Overall, the 
program facilitates trade and investment (OP7). The program focuses on strengthening the 
capacity of domestic financial institutions to encourage and expand access to banking and 
financial services in DMCs.  It has a demonstration effect on nonpartner financial institutions that 
are not yet providing supply chain finance. The program contributes to reducing poverty and 
inequalities (OP1) by providing greater access to finance for SMEs in DMCs and will create jobs, 
stimulate growth, and improve livelihoods. The program also promotes gender equality in banking 
through training and workshops for female bank staff in DMCs (OP2). The program is also aligned 
with the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).17 
 
32.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. Inclusive finance is 
one of the three pillars of ADB’s Financial Sector Operational Plan, which was reaffirmed in its 
2017  review.18One  component  of  the  strategic  focus  of  ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department is to mobilize third-party capital through credit enhancement products and risk 
transfer arrangements. The program facilitates this by encouraging private sector contributions to 
supply chain finance and enabling ADB to support SMEs. 
 
 
15 United Nations Sustainable Development Knowledge Platform. Sustainable Development Goal 8 (target 8.10). 
16 ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
17 United Nations Development Programme. 2015. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. New York. 
18 ADB. 2017. Review of 2011 Financial Sector Operational Plan. Manila.

9 
 
V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
33.  The program will continue to be classified as category FI treated as C across all three 
safeguard requirements under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). Through its PFIs and 
obligors, the program will provide access to working capital for SMEs, suppliers, and distributors, 
helping them increase production and contributing to their growth and development. The business 
activities that will be supported by the PFIs and obligors are anticipated to have minimal or no 
adverse environmental and involuntary resettlement impacts and are unlikely to entail indigenous 
peoples  impacts.  ADB  will  ensure  that  the  underlying  goods  for  each  transaction  will  not 
contravene the excluded goods list patterned after ADB’s prohibited investment activities list. ADB 
funds will not be used for transactions classified as category A and category B for environment, 
involuntary  resettlement,  or  indigenous  peoples.  There  are  no  recorded  or  outstanding 
noncompliance issues with existing safeguards and social requirements in the program. The 
program team and PFIs will comply with the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and relevant 
national laws, including labor laws; will take measures to comply with internationally recognized 
core labor standards; and will report on participants’ compliance in the annual report. 
 
34.   Effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  program’s  revised  gender  classification  is 
effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development (1998),19 
the  program  has  incorporated  measures  to  promote  gender  equality  and/or  women’s 
empowerment in its business activities. Key features of the gender action plan are as follows: 
(i) improved knowledge of DMC banks participating in the ADB SCFP TA on gender lens financing 
in supply  chain finance;  (ii)  increased capability  of the  participating  banks to  apply  a sex-
disaggregated data system; (iii) increased number of their women staff receiving supply chain 
finance capacity building training; and (iv) in collaboration with the TFP, the introduction of a 
training program focused on improving their customer service to female clientele. The program 
will include periodic reports on implementation of gender measures in its reporting system. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
35.  PFIs and obligors (when providing direct financing) will be advised of ADB’s policy of 
implementing best international practices relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and 
the financing of terrorism.20 ADB will ensure that the documentation includes (i) appropriate 
provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism;  and 
(ii) remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
36.  The program’s current financing is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and 
single-investment exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
 
37.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),21 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that participating governments 
that have yet to declare no objection to the proposed assistance will be asked to do so before the 
 
19 ADB. 1998. Policy on Gender and Development. Manila. 
20 Prospective PFIs and obligors benefiting from stand-alone debt financing will be advised of the policy. 
21 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

10 
 
program is implemented in their country. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in 
form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the 
ADB Board of Directors. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed major change in scope to the Supply Chain Finance 
Program would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and 
recommend that the Board approves the major change in scope (as described in para. 21 above) 
with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this 
report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa 
President

metadata.Subject:
The major change in scope of the Supply Chain Finance Program (SCFP) entails: (i) the incorporation on a permanent basis of the following changes to the program, originally approved on a temporary basis as part of the ADB's Comprehensive Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic; and (ii) the ability to undertake unfunded risk participations in working capital loans and guarantees each with a maximum tenor of 12 months.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated June 2021 is provided for the ADB regional project 46920-015.
